questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following is secreted from acidophilic cells of pituitary?
questions.explanation: Growth hormone is secreted from acidophilic cells of anterior pituitary. Acidophilic cells secrete growth hormone and prolactin. Basophilic cells secrete TSH, ACTH, FSH and LH.

questions.question:
Question 2: A 40-year-old man is suffering from hypertension, buffalo hump and hyperpigmentation of 
the skin, including oral mucosa. He is diagnosed with Cushing syndrome due to pituitary 
cause. Which of the following is responsible for the hyperpigmentation seen in this patient?
questions.explanation:
ACTH is more responsible than MSH for the hyperpigmentation seen in a patient with Cushing 
syndrome due to pituitary cause (ACTH hypersecretion). ACTH is a derivative of POMC (Pro-opiomelanocortin). POMC is the precursor of ACTH, 
melanocyte stimulating hormone (MSH),  lipotropin and  endorphin. Since the 
melanocyte-stimulating hormone is the byproduct of ACTH synthesis from POMC, any disease 
process which leads to ACTH overproduction will also lead to an increased level of MSH. ACTH 
has mild MSH activity, hence elevated levels of ACTH acts on melanotropin-1 receptors causing 
generalized hyperpigmentation. A similar manifestation will also be seen in Addison's disease where the ACTH level is high.

questions.question: Question 3: Inhibitory control by the hypothalamus is exerted on:
questions.explanation:
Inhibitory control by the hypothalamus is exerted mainly on prolactin and growth hormone. The major hypothalamic releasing hormones are: • Thyrotropin releasing hormone (TRH) • Corticotropin releasing hormone (CRH) 702 
Sold by @itachibot • Growth hormone releasing hormone (GHRH) • Gonadotropin releasing hormone (GnRH) The major hypothalamic inhibitory hormones are: • Prolactin inhibitory hormone or dopamine • Growth hormone inhibitory hormone (GHIH), also called Somatostatin.

questions.question:
Question 4: A patient with a known brain tumour learns that his pituitary stalk has been affected. 
Secretion of which of the following hormones is increased after the sectioning of the pituitary 
stalk? 695 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The secretion of prolactin is increased after the sectioning of the pituitary stalk. Prolactin is unique among the pituitary hormones because the predominant central control 
mechanism is inhibitory, i.e., dopamine inhibits prolactin secretion. Hence, sectioning of the 
pituitary stalk (Ex: In head trauma or compressive skull lesions) prevents this inhibition and leads 
to increased secretion of prolactin. Note: If the pituitary stalk is cut above the pituitary gland but the entire hypothalamus is left intact, the 
posterior pituitary hormones (ADH & Oxytocin) show a transient decrease because they are 
initially synthesized in the supraoptic and paraventricular nuclei of the hypothalamus and are 
then transported down to the nerve endings to the posterior pituitary gland, requiring several 
days to reach the gland.

questions.question: Question 5: Which of the following is not a cause of elevated prolactin level?
questions.explanation:
L- Dopa is not a cause of increased prolactin level, it decreases prolactin secretion by increasing 
the formation of dopamine (prolactin inhibitory hormone).

questions.question: Question 6: Which of the following is the effect of continuous GnRH administration?
questions.explanation:
Continuous GnRH administration suppresses the hypothalamic-pituitary axis. Pulsatile GnRH stimulates the pulsatile release of LH and FSH. Note: Long-acting GnRH agonists are used to suppress gonadotropin levels in children with 
precocious puberty and in men with prostate cancer.

questions.question: Question 7: Which of the following actions of GH is mediated by IGF–1?
questions.explanation:
Antilipolysis is mediated by IGF-1. The actions of growth hormone-mediated via IGF-1 (somatomedin-C) are the indirect effects of 
growth hormone and include: 703 
Sold by @itachibot • Antilipolytic activity • Insulin-like activity • Protein synthesis • Epiphyseal growth The direct effects of GH include: • Sodium retention • Decreased insulin sensitivity • Lipolysis • Protein synthesis • Epiphyseal growth

questions.question: Question 8: GH has its effect on bone growth through
questions.explanation:
Growth hormone (GH) has both direct and indirect effects on bone growth. GH stimulates prechondrocytes to differentiate into chondrocytes. GH strongly stimulates 
osteoblasts and chondrocytes causing increased deposition of proteins  bone growth. GH also 
increases insulin-like growth factor (IGF) levels, which stimulate bone growth. Note: The pygmies of Africa have a congenital inability to synthesize significant amounts of 
somatomedin C (IGF-I). Therefore, even though their plasma concentration of growth hormone is 
either normal or high, they have diminished amounts of IGF-I in the plasma, which accounts for 
the short stature. Some other dwarfs (e.g., the Levi-Lorain dwarf) also have this problem.

questions.question: Question 9: Which of the following hormones demonstrates the fluctuations depicted below?
questions.explanation:
Growth hormone demonstrates the depicted fluctuations. Growth hormone is secreted in a 
pulsatile fashion, with increase during strenuous exercise and during the early period of sleep, 
(Non-REM Sleep) as shown in the graph. It is reduced during the later stages of sleep. (REM 
sleep) Other options: Option A: ACTH levels are high in the early morning and low in the late evening. Option C: TSH is secreted in pulses, but the fluctuations are less in comparison to other pituitary 
hormones because of the low amplitude of the pulses and the relatively long half-life of TSH. Option D: Prolactin is secreted in a pulsatile fashion, with the highest secretory peak between 
4:00 and 6:00 a.m. (REM Sleep)

questions.question: Question 10: Growth hormone level is decreased in which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation:
704 
Sold by @itachibot Growth hormone(GH) level is decreased during deep sleep. Specifically, it is reduced during REM 
sleep as the levels of GHRH reduces and levels of cortisol are higher compared to slow wave sleep. Hypoglycemia, fasting, and exercise cause an increase in GH secretion. GH levels are increased 
during non-REM sleep. GH levels also decline with age and obesity.

questions.question:
Question 11: 697 
Sold by @itachibot A 35 yr old man presents with hypertension, coarse facial features, frontal bossing, large 
hands and feet, mandibular enlargement and a large fleshy nose. His age-matched serum 
IGF-I levels are elevated. What is the most likely cause of his condition?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acromegaly and is due to excess growth hormone (GH). Acromegaly occurs when excessive GH is secreted after puberty (after fusion of long bone 
epiphysis). Features include • Prognathism (protrusion of jaw), hypertrophy of frontal bones • Acral enlargement in hands and feet (due to thickening of soft tissues) • Visceromegaly: Enlargement of most organs especially the tongue, thyroid, salivary gland, liver, 
spleen, kidney, and prostate Serious complications include cardiomyopathy with arrhythmias, diabetes mellitus, obstructive 
sleep apnoea, and increased risk of colonic polyps and cancer. Age-matched IGF-I levels are 
elevated.

questions.question: Question 12: What does the neurohypophysis release?
questions.explanation:
The posterior pituitary or neurohypophysis releases oxytocin and anti-diuretic hormone (ADH or 
vasopressin) Note: ADH and oxytocin are synthesised by the supraoptic and paraventricular nuclei of the 
hypothalamus. Thereafter, they are stored and released from the posterior pituitary. 705 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 13: Which pair of vasopressin receptors is incorrect?
questions.explanation: The pair V4-CNS is incorrect. Vasopressin mediates its effect via 3 kinds of receptors- V1a, V1b and V2. There is no V4.

questions.question: Question 14: "Vasopressin escape" in SIADH results due to:
questions.explanation:
Vasopressin escape in SIADH (Syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion) results due to 
downregulation of aquaporin 2 production. Prolonged exposure to elevated levels of vasopressin (ADH) leads eventually to downregulation of 
aquaporin-2 receptors. This prevents excessive reabsorption of water, despite high serum ADH 
levels and hence maintains euvolemia. This is known as vasopressin escape. This helps prevent 
excessive dilutional hyponatremia in SIADH.

questions.question:
Question 15: 698 
Sold by @itachibot Sodium-iodide symport is absent in which of the following sites?
questions.explanation: Sodium-iodide symport is absent in the pituitary. Na+/I– symporter is present in • Basolateral membranes of thyrocytes facing the capillaries. • Salivary glands • Gastric mucosa • Placenta • Ciliary body of the eye • Choroid plexus • Mammary glands

questions.question:
Question 16: A 35-year-old lady is diagnosed with Hashimoto thyroiditis and a positive antibody titer 
against thyroid peroxidase enzyme. Which of the following is not a function of the affected 
enzyme?
questions.explanation:
Iodide trapping (iodide uptake) is not catalyzed by thyroid peroxidase. Oxidation, organification, 
and coupling are catalyzed by it. Steps in synthesis and secretion of thyroid hormone: • Iodide uptake: The basolateral sodium-iodide symporter (NIS) actively takes up I-(iodide) from 
the circulation into the follicular cells. It is then transported into the colloid through a pendrin 
(chloride-iodide) transporter 706 
Sold by @itachibot • Thyroglobulin synthesis: Thyroglobulin (Tg), is a large glycoprotein rich in tyrosine residues. It is 
synthesized by follicular cells. • Iodination of thyroglobulin: This is regulated by the thyroid peroxidase (TPO) enzyme. TPO has 
three functions: • Oxidation: TPO oxidizes I- to I2 (iodine) in the presence of H2O2 • Organification: TPO links tyrosine residues of thyroglobulin with iodine (I2) to form 
monoiodotyrosine (MIT), diiodotyrosine (DIT) • Coupling reactions: TPO combines iodinated tyrosine residues to make MIT + DIT = T3 
(triiodothyronine), DIT + DIT = T4 (tetraiodothyronine) • Storage: Thyroid hormones are bound to thyroglobulin and stored in the follicular lumen as 
colloids. The colloid has hormone reserves for 2-3 months • Release: Iodinated thyroglobulin is taken up by the thyroid follicles via endocytosis and fuses 
with lysosomes. It is cleaved by lysosomal proteolytic enzymes into MIT, DIT, T3, and T4. T4 
(80%) and T3 (20%) are released into the blood • Peripheral T3 conversion: T4 undergoes deiodination in extrathyroidal tissue to form T3, which 
is the active form of the hormone

questions.question:
Question 17: A patient with hyperthyroidism is planned for thyroidectomy. In order to achieve a euthyroid 
status preoperatively, he is started on Lugol's iodine solution. Which of the following best 
describes its mechanism of action?

options.d: Inhibition of organification and synthesis of thyroid hormones

questions.explanation:
Introduction of exogenous iodine in the form of lugol's iodine solution leads to transient 
inhibition of organification and synthesis of thyroid hormones. This is known as the wolff-chaikoff 
effect. In individuals with a normal thyroid, the gland escapes from this inhibitory effect and iodide 
organification resumes; but the suppressive action of high iodide may persist in patients with 
hyperthyroidism due to underlying autoimmune thyroid disease. 707 
Sold by @itachibot Note: Jod-Basedow effect is iodine-induced hyperthyroidism, usually occurring after the use of an 
I-based contrast agent. It is often seen in the presence of pre-existing thyroid conditions like 
multinodular goitre.

questions.question: Question 18: How long is thyroxine stored in thyroid follicles?
questions.explanation:
Thyroxine is stored in the thyroid follicles for 2-3 months, bound to thyroglobulin. Serves as a reserve of T3 and T4, thus delaying the occurrence of hypothyroidism, if thyroid 
secretion ceases.

questions.question:
Question 19: The major thyroxine-binding protein is  
.
questions.explanation: Thyroxine-binding globulin (TBG) is the major thyroxine-binding protein. Other thyroxine-binding proteins are: • Albumin • Transthyretin (TTR)/ thyroxine-binding pre-albumin (TBPA) • Lipoproteins

questions.question: Question 21: Half-life of T4
questions.explanation: The half-life of T4 is 6 - 7 days. T3 has the shorter half-life of 1 day.

questions.question:
Question 22: A 35 yr old woman presents with heat intolerance and menstrual abnormalities. On 
examination, a diffusely enlarged thyroid gland is present. Which of the following features 
will not be present in her?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of hyperthyroidism, which does not cause decreased 
protein breakdown. Rather it causes increased protein breakdown.

questions.question: Question 23: Prolactin level is highest during :
questions.explanation:
Among the given options, the prolactin level is highest 24 hours after delivery. The maximum level of prolactin is seen during pregnancy and in the immediate postpartum 
period. During pregnancy, the secretion is increased reaching a peak at the time of delivery. After 
delivery, the plasma concentration falls to nonpregnant levels in a few weeks. Suckling produces 
surges of prolactin release.

questions.question: Question 24: Which of the following conditions would have the highest levels of ACTH and cortisol?
questions.explanation:
Among the given conditions, the levels of ACTH and cortisol will be highest in Cushing's disease. Cushing’s disease is caused by an ACTH secreting pituitary adenoma. The increased ACTH causes 
increased cortisol production. Note: In normal physiologic state, ACTH levels are higher in the early morning but not as high as 
in Cushing's disease. 709
